name: Allegheny Islands State Park
remarks: Three alluvial islands near Pittsburgh with no facilities, and accessible only by boat

name: Archbald Pothole State Park
remarks: One of world's largest potholes, 38 ft (12 m) deep, largest diameter 42 feet (13 m) by 24 feet (7 m)

name: Bald Eagle State Park
remarks: 1,730 acre (700 ha) U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoir named for Medal of Honor recipient

name: Beltzville State Park
remarks: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers lake is 949 acres (384 ha) with 19.8 miles (31.9 km) of shoreline.

name: Bendigo State Park
remarks: Only 20 acres (8.1 ha) developed, name a corruption of Abednego

name: Benjamin Rush State Park
remarks: Site of one of the world's largest community gardens, otherwise undeveloped

name: Big Pocono State Park
remarks: On Camelback Mountain, site of Camelback Ski Area and Waterpark

name: Big Spring State Forest Picnic Area
remarks: Park has trail to partially completed railroad tunnel in Conococheague Mountain.

name: Black Moshannon State Park
remarks: Park has bog with three carnivorous plant species and 17 orchid varieties.

name: Blue Knob State Park
remarks: This former Recreation Demonstration Area on the state's second highest mountain has Blue Knob All Seasons Resort (skiing).

name: Boyd Big Tree Preserve Conservation Area
remarks: On Blue Mountain, one of three Conservation Areas, named for donor Alex Boyd

name: Buchanan's Birthplace State Park
remarks: Stone pyramid marks the birthplace of James Buchanan, 15th President of the United States.

name: Bucktail State Park Natural Area
remarks: Park, named for the Bucktail Regiment, is a 75-mile (121 km) undeveloped scenic drive on PA 120.

name: Caledonia State Park
remarks: Park, named for Thaddeus Stevens' iron furnace, is home to summer stock Totem Pole Playhouse.

name: Canoe Creek State Park
remarks: Home of largest nursery colony of little brown bats in the state.

name: Chapman State Park
remarks: Trailhead for trail system in surrounding Allegheny National Forest

name: Cherry Springs State Park
remarks: Park known for some of the clearest, darkest night skies in the state and eastern US.

name: Clear Creek State Park
remarks: Start of popular canoe trip on 10 miles (6 km) of Clarion River to Cook Forest State Park

name: Codorus State Park
remarks: Man-made lake is 1,275 acres (516 ha), named for former village of Marburg now flooded by it.

name: Colonel Denning State Park
remarks: Park named for William Denning, an American Revolutionary War veteran who was never a colonel.

name: Colton Point State Park
remarks: On west rim of the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon, 800 feet (244 m) deep here

name: Cook Forest State Park
remarks: National Natural Landmark, one of America's top-50 state parks (National Geographic Traveler)

name: Cowans Gap State Park
remarks: Site of French and Indian War road, pioneer homestead, lumbering, and CCC camp

name: Delaware Canal State Park
remarks: Park runs 60 miles (97 km) along Delaware Canal, the only 19th century U.S. towpath canal left continuously intact.

name: Denton Hill State Park
remarks: Site of Ski Denton resort, also open for summer mountain biking

name: Elk State Park
remarks: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers lake is 1,160 acres (470 ha).

name: Erie Bluffs State Park
remarks: Park has 1.0 mile (0.6 km) of lake coastline and bluffs 90 feet (27 m) tall, and is being developed.

name: Evansburg State Park
remarks: Park has 18 hole Skippack Golf Course and many outdoor recreational opportunities.

name: Fort Washington State Park
remarks: George Washington camped here in the American Revolutionary War's Philadelphia campaign.

name: Fowlers Hollow State Park
remarks: Trailhead for the trail system of the surrounding Tuscarora State Forest

name: Frances Slocum State Park
remarks: Park named for a girl kidnapped by the Lenape who lived the rest of her life with the Miami in Indiana.

name: French Creek State Park
remarks: Former Recreation Demonstration Area, adjacent to Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site

name: Gifford Pinchot State Park
remarks: Gifford Pinchot was a Pennsylvania governor, conservationist, and first US Forest Service Chief.

name: Gouldsboro State Park
remarks: Park named for village named for Jay Gould, next to Tobyhanna Army Depot.

name: Greenwood Furnace State Park
remarks: Includes ghost town of Greenwood, former ironworks and charcoal hearths

name: Hickory Run State Park
remarks: Former Recreation Demonstration Area with a large boulder field that is a National Natural Landmark.

name: Hillman State Park
remarks: Managed for hunting by the Pennsylvania Game Commission and largely undeveloped

name: Hills Creek State Park
remarks: Land previously used as a pigment mine for the paint industry

name: Hyner Run State Park
remarks: On the site of Civilian Conservation Corps Camp S-75-PA

name: Hyner View State Park
remarks: Scenic view of the West Branch Susquehanna River and launching point for hang gliding

name: Jacobsburg Environmental Education Center
remarks: Park surrounds Jacobsburg National Historic District, where rifles were manufactured during the American Revolution.

name: Jennings Environmental Education Center
remarks: Park contains the only publicly protected relict prairie ecosystem in Pennsylvania, 20 acres (8.1 ha).

name: Joseph E. Ibberson Conservation Area
remarks: On Peters Mountain, one of three Conservation Areas, named for donor Joseph E. Ibberson

name: Kettle Creek State Park
remarks: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoir is 160 acres (65 ha), park has many recreational facilities built by CCC.

name: Keystone State Park
remarks: Park is named for the Keystone Coal and Coke Company that once owned the land and created the lake.

name: Kings Gap Environmental Education and Training Center
remarks: Training center for park rangers of the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources

name: Kinzua Bridge State Park
remarks: Had 1882 Historic Civil Engineering Landmark railway bridge, once the world's highest and longest, destroyed by a tornado in 2003.

name: Kooser State Park
remarks: Site of battles between Native American tribes, part of Whiskey Rebellion

name: Lackawanna State Park
remarks: On site of a Turn of the Century era community fair

name: Laurel Hill State Park
remarks: Former Recreation Demonstration Area with the largest CCC architecture collection of any Pennsylvania state park

name: Laurel Mountain State Park
remarks: Opened in 1939 by Richard K. Mellon and Rolling Rock brewery as one of the state's first ski areas, donated to the state in 1964

name: Laurel Ridge State Park
location: Cambria, Fayette, Somerset and Westmoreland Counties
remarks: The park surrounds the 70 mile (113 km) long Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail.

name: Laurel Summit State Park
remarks: Day use picnic area and trailhead, 2,739 feet (835 m) above sea level

name: Lehigh Gorge State Park
remarks: The Lehigh Gorge Trail follows the river through the park for 26 miles (42 km).

name: Leonard Harrison State Park
remarks: On east rim of the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon, 800 feet (244 m) deep here

name: Linn Run State Park
remarks: Once a barren wasteland, now a thriving second growth forest with an excellent trout stream

name: Little Buffalo State Park
remarks: Park named for the bison that are believed to have once roamed the ridge and valley region of Pennsylvania.

name: Little Pine State Park
remarks: Historians believe a Shawnee village and burial ground were just north of the park.

name: Locust Lake State Park
remarks: In a thriving second growth forest on the side of Locust Mountain

name: Lyman Run State Park
remarks: Site of a Prisoner of War Camp during World War II

name: Marsh Creek State Park
remarks: The village of Milford Mills was flooded by the creation of the lake, last Project 70 / 500 park.

name: Maurice K. Goddard State Park
remarks: Park named for Maurice K. Goddard, who led the creation of 45 state parks in 24 years of service.

name: McCalls Dam State Park
remarks: In a remote location on a dirt road between  R. B. Winter State Park and Eastville.

name: McConnells Mill State Park
remarks: Features a deep scenic gorge with a restored watermill and a covered bridge

name: Memorial Lake State Park
remarks: Surrounded by Fort Indiantown Gap, headquarters of the Pennsylvania National Guard

name: Milton State Park
remarks: On an island in the river, destroyed by Hurricane Agnes in 1972 and rebuilt

name: Mont Alto State Park
remarks: Pennsylvania's current oldest state park and first State Forest Park, former iron works

name: Moraine State Park
remarks: Park served as the location of the 1973 and 1977 National Scout Jamborees.

name: Mt. Pisgah State Park
remarks: Lake named for renowned American composer Stephen Foster.

name: Nescopeck State Park
remarks: One of the newest state parks in Pennsylvania

name: Neshaminy State Park
remarks: Park, on an estuary, donated by descendant of James Logan, colonial secretary to William Penn

name: Nockamixon State Park
remarks: Nockamixon means "place of soft soil" in the Lenape language.

name: Nolde Forest Environmental Education Center
remarks: Once a forest privately owned by Jacob Nolde

name: Norristown Farm Park
remarks: Managed by the Montgomery County Department of Parks

name: Ohiopyle State Park
remarks: One of the most popular white-water rafting destinations on the East Coast

name: Oil Creek State Park
remarks: Edwin Drake drilled the first successful oil well in the world here in 1859.

name: Ole Bull State Park
remarks: Location of a Norwegian colony established by renowned violinist Ole Bull

name: Parker Dam State Park
remarks: A herd of elk lives in and near the park.

name: Patterson State Park
remarks: Day use picnic area on PA 44, surrounded by Susquehannock State Forest

name: Penn-Roosevelt State Park
remarks: Once a segregated black Civilian Conservation Corps camp during the Great Depression

name: Pine Grove Furnace State Park
remarks: The furnaces at Pine Grove could consume an acre of trees a day.

name: Poe Paddy State Park
remarks: Noted by anglers for the shadfly hatch that occurs in late spring

name: Poe Valley State Park
remarks: Built during the Great Depression by the CCC

name: Point State Park
remarks: In downtown Pittsburgh at meeting of three rivers, site of Fort Pitt

name: Presque Isle State Park
remarks: The most visited state park in Pennsylvania, on a peninsula in lake with many beaches

name: Prince Gallitzin State Park
remarks: Park named for Demetrius Gallitzin, Russian nobleman turned Roman Catholic priest.

name: Promised Land State Park
remarks: Name is an ironic commentary created by immigrant residents, once owned by the Shakers.

name: Prompton State Park
remarks: Being developed with the help of Friends of Prompton

name: Prouty Place State Park
remarks: Day use picnic area on Long Toe Road

name: Pymatuning State Park
remarks: This is the largest state park in Pennsylvania, with one of the largest lakes.

name: R. B. Winter State Park
remarks: Park has first cement and stone dam ever built by the Civilian Conservation Corps.

name: Raccoon Creek State Park
remarks: Park was built by the CCC and WPA as one of five National Park Service Recreation Demonstration Areas in state.

name: Ralph Stover State Park
remarks: High Rocks portion of the park was donated to Pennsylvania by James Michener in 1956.

name: Ravensburg State Park
remarks: Park named for the ravens that flock near the gorge.

name: Reeds Gap State Park
remarks: Once a gathering place for the locals to hold picnics and listen to travelling evangelists

name: Ricketts Glen State Park
remarks: Known for its many waterfalls, it was slated to become a National Park, but did not due to redirection of funds during World War II.

name: Ridley Creek State Park
remarks: Adjacent to the John J. Tyler Arboretum

name: Ryerson Station State Park
remarks: 52 acre (21 ha) man-made lake, 38 miles (61 km) from next nearest Pennsylvania state park (Hillman)

name: S. B. Elliott State Park
remarks: Park named for Simon B. Elliott, a noted Pennsylvania conservationist and legislator.

name: Salt Springs State Park
remarks: Park has three waterfalls and its hemlocks are over 500 years old and some of the largest trees in the state.

name: Samuel S. Lewis State Park
remarks: Park named for its donor, a Secretary of the Department of Forests and Waters; now popular for star gazing.

name: Sand Bridge State Park
remarks: This is the smallest state park in Pennsylvania, a day use picnic area on PA 192.

name: Shawnee State Park
remarks: Rental lodge on an island in the lake

name: Shikellamy State Park
remarks: Park overlook is at confluence of West Branch and North Branch Susquehanna River, marina added in 1972.

name: Sinnemahoning State Park
remarks: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers reservoir is 142 acres (57 ha), park home to rare elk and bald eagle.

name: Sizerville State Park
remarks: Park named for the nearby ghost town of Sizerville.

name: Susquehanna State Park
remarks: Park operated by the Williamsport/Lycoming Chamber of Commerce, home to paddlewheeler Hiawatha.

name: Susquehannock State Park
remarks: Park named for the Susquehannock, whose chief village was nearby.

name: Swatara State Park
remarks: Rail trail is on the former Lebanon & Tremont Branch of Philadelphia & Reading Railroad, park being developed.

name: Tobyhanna State Park
remarks: Once part of an artillery range for Tobyhanna Army Depot

name: Trough Creek State Park
remarks: Bald eagles have migrated here naturally since the early 1990s.

name: Tuscarora State Park
remarks: The Tuscarora moved to the area after the Tuscarora War in North Carolina, were later forced out by colonial settlement.

name: Tyler State Park
remarks: Old original stone dwellings in park are fine examples of early farm dwellings of rural Pennsylvania.

name: Upper Pine Bottom State Park
remarks: A roadside park and picnic area for day use only, on PA 44

name: Varden Conservation Area
remarks: One of three Conservation Areas, donated by Dr. Mead Shaffer, being developed

name: Warriors Path State Park
remarks: Park named for the Great Indian Warpath used by the Iroquois in war raids on the Cherokee and other tribes.

name: Washington Crossing Historic Park
remarks: Site of George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River. Transferred from the Historical and Museum Commission in 2016.

name: Whipple Dam State Park
remarks: There was a camp for Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, and Campfire Girls on the north side of lake from 1928 to 1941.

name: White Clay Creek Preserve
remarks: Park was donated by DuPont to preserve "diverse and unique plant and animal species, and the rich cultural heritage of the area".

name: Worlds End State Park
remarks: A "Must See Park" known for trout fishing, white-water kayaking, camping, and hiking on the Loyalsock Trail.

name: Yellow Creek State Park
remarks: Crossed by the Kittanning Path, a major eastâ€“west Native American trail during the 18th century
